speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 09-150, Michigan v. Bryant. Ms. Palmer.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, it can't all be the formality of the context.  I mean, if the police came in and said, well, has this person -- Rick, I guess -- sold you drugs before, what was the -- what was the quantity, and all those sorts of questions, the answers to that would be testimonial, despite the same lack of formality.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How do we --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Forget about formality, in other words.  Formality or no formality has nothing to do with it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How do we tell that? Because it seems to me, here, if you want to know what happened, you'd ask the very same questions.  You're saying the questions are relevant also to securing the situation.  But what -- what different questions would you ask if you wanted to find out what happened?  What was the past -- what were the past events? I mean, I'm trying to understand how you take these questions and say we can put a label on them here that says, well, this is to control an emergency situation versus we want to know what happened historically.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But whose primary purpose is it? I mean, the victim here knew that the incident hadn't happened there.  There was nothing he had to share with the police, because they could see he was bleeding from his stomach and he had been shot.  He  apparently didn't fear any threat, or there doesn't seem to be any circumstances suggesting an immediate threat to him.  He had driven away.  Rick didn't know where he had gone. So what's the ongoing emergency to the victim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, wait a minute. What is the primary -- isn't -- doesn't -- isn't there a footnote that says the primary purpose of the declarant is what is at issue?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That is -- that is what it says.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's the -- it's the -- it's the purpose of the declarant, not of the questioner.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, in Davis, the issue is why was the declarant talking?  What you were trying to do was to figure out whether the declarant was seeking help or attempting to get someone arrested. That's how I read the situation. The questions provided context for that. Are you seeking immediate ongoing help or are you talking about an event, attempting to get the police to intercede and arrest the person? Isn't that a fair reading of that case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: In a situation like this, do you think it's meaningful to ask what the primary purpose of the victim was when he responded to the police and said who shot him? You have a man who has just been shot.  He  has a wound that's going to turn out to be fatal, and he's lying there on the ground bleeding profusely, and he says:  My primary purpose in saying this is so that they can respond to an ongoing emergency.  No, but I also have the purpose of giving them information that could be used at trial, but it's a little less -- that's a little bit less my purpose than responding to the ongoing emergency. It seems like it's totally artificial.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What possible response to an ongoing emergency could he have had in mind?  What possible response to an ongoing emergency?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He was bleeding to death, and he could have said, you know, I'm bleeding to death. Now, that statement would -- would be, you know, suggesting an ongoing emergency. But giving the name of the person who shot him, where he was shot, what does that have anything -- how does that have anything to do with an ongoing  emergency?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But he does.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But he does.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He knows -- he knows that his -- that the person that shot him is nowhere near there.  He knows that -- that he drove, what -- how far away was it?  Six blocks or -- a good distance from where the shooter was.  He knows all of that. The only reason he could be giving the name of the person who shot him is so that person could be apprehended and punished.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Suppose he had -- suppose he had survived.  Suppose Covington had survived --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- instead of died.  And  then the prosecutor says, I want to introduce this evidence against Bryant.  Would you say that, yes, it's nontestimonial, so it comes in?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But why, if it's nontestimonial?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If you said -- you said it's -- you're typing it nontestimonial.  It goes to emergency situations.  So I'm saying:  Would that carry over to the man survives and the prosecutor says, I don't need to put him on the stand so he can be cross-examined; I've got nontestimonial evidence that I can put in? Would it become testimonial, then, if he survived?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But then -- then your answer is that if we typed it as nontestimonial in my trial scenario, it would be nontestimonial; it comes in.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm confused of what -- what Davis focuses our inquiry on.  Is it the purpose of the interrogators or is it the purpose of the declarants? We say the statements are testimonial when the circumstances objectively indicate that there is no such ongoing emergency and that the primary purpose of the interrogation is to establish or prove past events. The -- the focus seems to be on the purpose of the interrogation, which seems to be the question of what the police thought, not what the -- the person dying thought.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes, I mean --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But what the  footnote -- I'm sorry to interrupt you, but what the footnote says is, in the final analysis, it's the declarant's statements, not the interrogator's question, that the Confrontation Clause requires us to evaluate. So which -- I guess, which is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: One way to evaluate those statements is what they are made in response to.  If they are made in response to a certain type of police inquiry, they are more likely to be testimonial.  And another kind -- you know, are you dying?  They are more likely not to be testimonial.  But it is ultimately the statements that -- that we have to evaluate, whether they are testimonial or not.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, then, how does that apply?  The officer says, what happened?  And the -- the declarant says, Rick shot me. Now, is that testimonial or not?  Because  the declarant knows he's 6 miles away.  It's not going to help them solve an emergency, but the police don't know that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, if it was an emergency, he wouldn't have asked, what happened?  He would ask, what is happening?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: To ask what happened is to ask the declarant to describe past events, which is testimonial.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And you -- you do not know if the man is running amok and threatening to shoot other people or if -- if he's drunk, if he's on a rampage, if it's a college campus, then it's -- it's --  it's a sniper.  You just don't know.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But you can --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And if you're worried about that, do you run immediately over to the person lying on the ground or do you examine the gas station first, rather than expose yourself to the -- to the shooter that you think is still in the gas station? The -- the behavior of the police here gave no indication that they thought they were in danger immediately and were interrogating this person in order to assess the danger to them.  That wasn't what they were after.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I'm not -- I'm not sure that policemen should read Crawford before they perform their -- their peacekeeping duties.  The -- no -- no one questions the right of the police to -- to ask these questions and to use the word either "happens"  or "happening" or "happened." The question is whether the -- the answers are later admissible.  Those are two different inquiries.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And, of course, Crawford rejects reliability as a criteria.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But what does that have to do -- we're back to the reliability test, really, because they didn't do anything wrong.  They were trying to assess the situation.  But that's what they do when any report of criminal activity occurs.  That's a different inquiry than the inquiry of why should that statement be permitted to be introduced at trial? It goes to the very essence of reliability.  Was the statement made under circumstances that would suggest an intent to testify?  That's really what you're getting at, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, you are, because you're trying to pigeonhole yourself into an ongoing emergency that suggests that in those situations, whatever the person is saying is okay because it was done to assess an emergency situation and not done for purposes of catching somebody, primary purpose of catching somebody.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So are you saying that the rule would be that whenever the perpetrator may be in the vicinity, then the police are pursuing an urgent emergency situation, rather than trying to find out what had -- the nature of the crime?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: For all crimes, or only for shooting crimes or knifing crimes?  For explosions? What kinds of crimes would qualify?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So at least whenever the police come upon somebody who has been the victim of a violent crime, whatever interrogation they conduct could plausibly be to -- to make sure that the person is not still nearby, and that testimony will always be admissible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, no, no.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Strike "designed to assess the risk."  You don't know what they're designed to do. These policemen didn't say we're assessing the risk. They just asked the questions.  And that's what is going to happen in future cases. And you're saying, whenever policemen come upon a victim of violent crime and said who did it, what's his name, all of that will always be admissible because they -- they could be assessing the risk, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What do you mean?  How could it possibly be admissible? First, there has to be a degree of formality, as the Court held in Hammon, sitting in the kitchen; and, second, it has to satisfy State hearsay tests.  So unless it's an exception to the hearsay rule, it is not admissible.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, of course, there are exceptions.  There could, in fact, there could be a co-conspirator exception.  There could be a dying declaration exception.  But what we're talking about is  whether the Constitution keeps it out, even though State law -- because, say, it's a co-conspirator exception -- would permit it in. So the answer is no, it's not the case that whenever you come across a victim of a crime and ask him questions, it's going to be admissible.  It depends. The State hearsay law, the exception, and whether there's a degree of formality, as there was in Hammon.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Only when he's excited, right?  Only when the victim who has been the object of a violent crime is excited. Or if State law doesn't apply and we're dealing with a Federal crime and Federal officers, right, and trial in Federal court?  And in that case, what Justice Breyer just said would not apply.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It would not apply?  There are -- there isn't a Federal hearsay rule?  And there are not exceptions that you have to satisfy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I thought there were, in my copy of the Federal Rules of Evidence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: In the -- if you had the benefit of hindsight, and this trial occurred before Davis, and so the prosecutor went on excited utterance, would you have instead tried to make a case that this was a dying declaration?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Ms. Kruger.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you distinguish between collecting evidence for a future prosecution and collecting evidence in order to pursue and arrest the felon?  Do you distinguish those two? And you can say these police -- these policemen weren't collecting evidence for a future prosecution; they just wanted to know who the shooter was and where he was so they could go get him.  Would that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Would that not be collecting evidence for a future prosecution?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you say it has to be for the purpose of a future prosecution.  Just -- just in order to an arrest and bring into jail the person who committed this crime, that doesn't qualify?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: When does that not exist in the case of a violent crime?  When does that not exist?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There's a violent criminal out there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.  So if you use a gun, a knife, or a machine gun, whatever the victim says gets admitted into evidence, because the police could -- could be not --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- not trying to get evidence, but just trying to safeguard society against the -- the felon on the loose?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought that's how you just described it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Who did it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's always the case. That's such a phony evasion of what the purpose of the testimonial rule is. That's always going to be the case, at least when there's a violent crime.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And you may as well take Crawford and throw it out, in -- in the majority of serious cases, if that's going to be your rule.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The crime was ongoing in -- in Davis when -- when the woman was on the phone with the operator.  It was ongoing.  She was seeking help from the emergency that was occurring to her at that moment.  There's nothing like that here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Did the police know that that was the case when they began the questioning?  Did the police know that this man was not on a rampage, that he was not going to act in self-defense when they came after him?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That he was not taking hostages?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Will they ever know that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, is that -- is that likely not always to be the case when -- when you come upon a person who has been the -- the victim of a violent crime? You could say it all the time.  No, they didn't know where the -- where the offender was, so whatever this person says comes in as evidence in a trial.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, how do you know that?  Because they would ask the same very questions if what they wanted was testimonial evidence.  So you can -- you can characterize that set of questions either way.  What would lead us to pick one rather than the other?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Let's say --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Let's say that we -- let's say that we agree with you that there was an emergency and the police were asking questions in order to mitigate the emergency. What would be the rationale for admitting this statement, then?  Is it more reliable?  Because if we say that, then we're undercutting Crawford, which says reliability is not the key. What is the reason for that?  Is it because the police likely have less motive to manipulate the -- the statements and to ask loaded questions?  That in itself, it seems to me, is a reliable -- but what's the -- assuming we adopt your distinction, what's the rationale for the distinction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do we look to the specific situation?  I mean, one of the officers zeroed in on the victim.  No one was looking around to see if anybody was lurking in the bushes.  Then, as far as protecting the public, do we take into account that this was between 3:30 and 4:00 in the morning when there are not likely to be many members of the public around?  Or do we just say you find someone who looks like he has  been the victim of a violent crime, doesn't matter whether the public is around or not, we -- that's enough, the victim of a violent crime can be asked these questions?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, but then you're saying that the focus is on the police officers.  I mean, after all, we're not saying that police officers can't do this; we're just saying the testimonial aspects can't be admitted into evidence or that's what your friend is arguing for.  I still have trouble figuring out is the issue the purpose of the interrogating officers or the purpose and intent of the declarant?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.  And what do you do with the last sentence of footnote 1.  It's the one that says --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right, right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Van Hoek.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I didn't hear the end.  In  locating and?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Apprehending.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- involves something like that, if -- what keeps that out?  I mean, assuming that a State law or the Federal Rules of Evidence admit it as an exception to the hearsay rule, why should the Confrontation Clause bar it?  There is not great likelihood that, like Sir Walter Raleigh or Cobham's affidavit, it is going to be introduced per se into the trial as a form of evidence that there was -- why would we want to keep it out?  That's the part that I do not understand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Federal -- I mean, under the Federal Constitution.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think your answer, counsel, is that we decided that in Crawford, from which Justice Breyer dissented. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I think you might have another --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Suppose I think we didn't. Suppose I happen to think --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Perhaps there is another answer that I would like to hear.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'd like to hear your answer because I don't think we decided it in Crawford.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Now is a good time to try to jump in, I think. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But does it mean -- does it mean that the individual is thinking this may be used --  there's a certain formality to the situation; it may be used at trial?  Or it may just happen to turn out?  I mean, what is the relevance of the formality of the situation?  When I looked into history I thought -- I'm not an expert in history, and I'm also -- I understand there have been situations where the Court's gone back to prior cases and looked at footnotes and said it doesn't express things precisely clearly and changed it a little bit.  I think that that goal could be open to us. So I want to know what the basic reason is that there -- that would justify keeping out, let's say, an investigation.  There's an investigation of a crime, and a policeman comes across a confederate who makes some statements just generally that help the investigation; therefore, it would come in under -- as co-conspiracy, okay? What in the Constitution, what functional principle, is there that says we should keep that out of Court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is it all hearsay?  Now, all -- all hearsay evidence, despite State or Federal rule makers saying there are exceptions where the trustworthiness is sufficient, such as co-confederates, confederates, all of that's wiped out by Crawford and the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's what we said in Crawford, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Of course, what I'm looking for now because I'm -- is whether there's any sense to that.  What is the constitutional rationale?  I joined Crawford, but I have to admit to you I've had many second thoughts when I've seen how far it has extended as I have written it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So now you've just got what I'm looking for.  What I'm looking for is I can go into Blackstone a little bit and look back and see what this was after, was the problem of Sir Walter Raleigh's trial and the Marian judges.  And now what I need is a line. Because if I can't find a line, then what we've done, which seems just as wrong to me, is suddenly bar virtually all hearsay exception evidence, of which for 400 years, or 200 years anyway, there has been quite a lot in the courts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What, in your view, is the correct line and why, most importantly why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: If it were established that this was a dying declaration and was done in -- made in  contemplation of death, would it be barred by Crawford?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, why not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I understand -- I understand that, but assume -- assume for the sake of argument that it would be consistent with Crawford if it were a dying declaration, which the Court has suggested.  What does that tell you about the understanding of the scope of the confrontation right at the time when the Sixth Amendment was adopted?  Because a dying declaration may very well be testimonial under -- is likely to be testimonial under the Crawford test.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I thought -- I thought the rationale for dying declaration admissions was that they are inherent reliable -- inherently reliable.  You can certainly question that.  But I thought that that was the rationale that the courts gave.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: On your death bed before you're going to meet the maker, you're not going to lie -- I think that was the test.  So it was a reliability component, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Now, suppose that there is a universe of instances that we can identify as questions in order to alleviate and stop an emergency to prevent a crime from becoming aggravated and continuous. Let's suppose we can have a universe of those questions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is -- is there an argument that responses made for that purpose are more reliable? Is that what -- is that what underlies the so-called emergency exception, do you think?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So it -- so -- well -- and, of course, Davis certainly does not rest on reliability -- or Crawford, rather, doesn't rest on reliability.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But isn't that really the only way to explain the 911 exception?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Isn't there a reliability component that underlies this whether we like it or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But isn't -- isn't the reason we accept that is because it's reliable?  It's an excited utterance.  It's an account of an ongoing event. It's a contemporaneous observation.  Therefore, it is reliable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Let's go back to this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Excited utterance was -- the prosecutor thought that was his best shot, and he -- and he prevailed, except that the -- Davis intervened. I asked Ms. Palmer, suppose we were back there at the trial and the prosecutor knew that excited utterance wouldn't work.  Could he have raised dying declaration?  She said absolutely yes.  So my question to you is:  Just assume that we should hold the Confrontation Clause is applicable. Shouldn't the prosecutor then have a chance to say, well, if I realized that, I could have made a dying declaration plea here.  So it would only be fair to allow the prosecutor to try to establish that this testimony was a dying declaration?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Then she did argue dying declaration.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And that -- that was in the pre-Davis world.  But do you think the prosecutor had abandoned that effort had he been informed about Davis?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Van Hoek, what is the basis for your concession that a dying declaration is an exception from the Confrontation Clause?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It is an exception from hearsay, for certain, but from the Confrontation Clause?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You conceded it.  It's been the whole basis for Justice Ginsburg's subsequent interrogation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: My question was based on it's an open question because we have said maybe a dying declaration.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought it was an open question only -- only where the -- the defendant has  effected the death of the person who has made the dying declaration.  I don't know of any cases that allow a dying declaration in over a Confrontation Clause objection.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And it wasn't -- and it wasn't in Giles.  It wasn't in --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If it hasn't been reached, if it is not an established exception to the Confrontation Clause, there is no basis for saying,  therefore, the Confrontation Clause pertains only to reliability.  It pertains to the opportunity to cross-examine. And -- and reliability exceptions are what we used to do under -- under Reynolds.  If it was reliable, we let it in.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And the mere fact that it's reliable as a dying declaration instead of reliable as something else ought to have nothing to do with the Confrontation Clause decision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Whether we -- whether you agree or not, we said it was an open question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Can there be --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Can there be a situation in which the primary purpose for a statement or for the question that elicits the statement is to respond to an ongoing emergency rather than to gather evidence for subsequent use in a legal proceeding when the statement relates to something that has occurred, perhaps just a few seconds before, but it relates to something that has  occurred as opposed to something that is occurring at that very moment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, I understand, but we need to know where to draw the line.  So, you concede that the line is not between a statement about he's hitting me with a baseball bat as opposed to he just finished hitting me with a baseball bat and is headed out the door?  That's not where the line is drawn.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: No, no.  I really would like a clear answer to this.  Is -- can there be an ongoing emergency where the statement relates -- where the  statement recounts something that has occurred, not something that is occurring?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So what do you do -- what do you do with the statement the guy in the gas station shot me?  Is that purely past, or is that an ongoing emergency?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Even though the guy in the gas station is still there with a gun, the police are within range?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes.  I mean, that strikes me as something that happened in the past, he shot me, but at the same time demonstrates an ongoing emergency because he's right there and he might shoot you.  I'm suggesting the line you propose to Justice Alito doesn't work.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The guy in the gas station is present.  It's not past.  He's making an assertion the guy who is now in the gas station shot me.  The "shot me" is past, but he's asserting that the person is now in the gas station.  That is a statement of a present fact.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, suppose they get a 9-1-1 call.  There's -- a man has just been shot on the corner of Fifth and Main.  They go to Fifth and Main; they find a man there; he's shot; he's bleeding profusely; he's in shock; and they know nothing more about what's happened.  And they say, well, what happened?  Well, he shot me.  Who shot you?  It's John  Jones. Now what about that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, the police under those circumstances don't know whether John Jones is going on a shooting spree; this is just the first of numerous victims.  Maybe it's a gang fight.  He's shot one member of an opposing gang; now he's going to go shoot another member of an opposing gang. How can they -- how can you answer that question, what's the primary purpose there?  I just don't understand it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But you -- you were the one that drew the line between a past event and an ongoing event.  Suppose the sniper says, I've shot you now, and I'm going to shoot three other students, good-bye.  That's a past event.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is there any -- I'll try this -- I think you're just -- you don't like my -- where I'm coming from, but -- and so you might not have an answer to this. But -- but in my mind, I see a line, and that line is dividing what I think of as the Confrontation Clause, Sir Walter Raleigh situation, which I have in my mind as people going into a room and saying, now write out your testimony, and they write it out in the form of an affidavit, or they send in a letter, and they say "bye," and then they walk next door to the trial and introduce it.  I mean, that's Walter Raleigh, in my mind. And then, on the other side of the line, is an -- evidentiary rules that are basically in State cases run by the State.  And they sometimes let hearsay in, and they sometimes don't, and they make reliability, et cetera, judgments in developing their -- their decision as to how hearsay exceptions will work.  Okay? Now, why don't I like emergency to draw that?  The reason I don't like the word "emergency" is I  think police do lots of things other than handle emergency and develop testimony. There's a range of things that you would describe as investigating the circumstance.  There's no danger.  There have been a string of robberies.  They go around and ask the grocery store people and everything what happened.  Now, I don't know why we should keep out evidence that, say, is given in that situation by a confederate.  It turns out he was the assistant -- why? And if I don't like that, I don't like the emergency rule as doing the -- as doing the work there, and I'm looking for something else. Now, you have my whole train of thought.  If you want to say, Judge, there is nothing but the emergency rule, you are perfectly free to say it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do it. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: They're not.  They're just asking -- all right.  Yes.  Go ahead.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.  They're investigating.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, yes, but in the past that situation you are describing arose only where there was a hearsay exception.  I would imagine most likely it would be the case of a confederate, someone who was part of the conspiracy.  So if I think if that's going to be the case, that probably will be admissible where this has bite.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And there be some others, excited utterances, maybe another.  Dying declarations are probably few and far between.  Baptismal certificates --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I know they did.  And what I'm saying is I'm finding that -- it seems to me that that line, if taken literally, would keep out exceptions to hearsay testimony, which have been well established in the United States for 200 years.  Baptismal certificates, statements of birth.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Confederates is the one I come back to.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay, okay.  I forgot --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I guess it depends on what you mean by "in the past," as Justice Breyer put it.  Undoubtedly, under the regime of United States v. Reynolds, which was what, 25 years old -- when --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Roberts.  I'm sorry.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No relation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Roberts.  I'm sorry. Roberts, which -- Reynolds was the Mormon case -- which was about 25 years old or so when Crawford was decided, yes, hearsay was your protection, and that was it.  But if by what you mean is in the past, Crawford examined the past, and its conclusion as to what the past said is quite different from what Justice Breyer now says, although he joined Crawford.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Many -- I mean, like many cases there is language that takes -- that can take us  far afield from the subject matter before us.  And I will admit that I did not foresee the scope of Crawford. So I'm really asking about that scope and, in particular, whether, looking to the past or to reason or to whatever you want, there is a good reason for keeping out the testimony of, say, a co-confederate, a co-conspirator, where it was elicited, not with intent to introduce it into the courtroom, but it was elicited in the course of an ordinary investigation of a crime.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, I'm still trying to  understand your conception of the scope of the ongoing emergency doctrine.  Would it be fair to say that your idea is that the police have to have specific evidence that there is an immediate threat of physical violence that they want -- they need to respond to, in order for the ongoing emergency doctrine to apply?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And in a case of doubt, they can't do it.  So if they don't know whether there is an immediate threat or not an immediate threat, then that doesn't fall within that exception.  That's your idea?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, they can always do it.  You -- you don't say they can't do it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They can always ask the questions.  The only issue here is not whether they can ask the questions, but whether, after they ask them, the answers can be introduced at trial.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I thought you just said that wasn't the test, past versus present.  Didn't you say that about 10 minutes ago -- it's not the difference between something that's taking place and something that has taken place?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: The witness has to say there is an emergency?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: There's a shooting -- there's a report of shooting at a school, and the police go and they find two students lying on the ground.  One is dead, and the other is severely wounded.  And they ask the one who is wounded:  Who did it?  It's John Jones. Now, does that -- is that an ongoing emergency.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: No?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Can he ask the witness --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, why is that not an ongoing emergency?  What would be an ongoing emergency?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: You have to have very specific information?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What if there are three students who have been shot, four students who have been shot, but nobody says, well, I think he's still in the building, he may have an interest in shooting some more students?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Would they ask his name? God, it's really important for us to know, four students on the ground.  What's the name of the guy that did this? That's not the emergency.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They'd say:  Where is he?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Of course that -- of course that's the emergency because how are they going to find the person that they -- that they're looking for if they don't know who it is?  What if he's thrown away his gun? Of course, if they come upon him and he has his gun in his hand, then it's not a question.  Bu what if he has disposed of it?  They have to know who to -- who to go for.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But I still -- I'm totally puzzled now as to what you -- when you think there's an ongoing emergency and when there isn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: It has to be made by the -- by the declarant?  It can't be inferred from the circumstances?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Oh, sure it can.  If he says the principal did it.  It's -- it's 10 o'clock in the morning; you assume the principal is at the school; and he says the principal did it.  You can infer from the circumstances that he's referring to an ongoing emergency.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, it's quite different than saying, you know, this happened to some guy driving by, or something like that.  If he says the principal did it, it's at 10 o'clock, it's in the school -- that suggests to me more, not that the dying student or the wounded student wanted to make sure that the principal was convicted, but that there's an emergency, something is happening.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You don't think there's a danger implicated by coming onto the lawn of a school and a student is there and says the principal shot me inside?  You don't think that that suggests an ongoing emergency, that the principal is still inside with a gun?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Oh, no, no.  You don't want them to have to go through, you know, a whole list of questions while the student's there dying and  the principal is inside the building shooting people?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Did he shoot you because he had a grudge against you, or is he just shooting --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- blindly, and he says he shot me?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Ms. Palmer, you have 2 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Let's go to formality. It can't be that you arrive at a scene of a crime and everything a victim tells you is admissible.  There has to be some emergency.  That's what we've said.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Correct?  So the issue here is how do you define that dividing line between emergency and non, when the police officers are just asking questions that by their nature are always going to be testimonial, because they are going to use or try to use whatever is said later?  So, in discerning the primary purpose, I think your adversary is saying you can't go by what the police officers are asking because they are going to be asking dual motive always.  You have to look to what the declarant tells you.  And is he or she telling you something that suggests an emergency?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's really the difference between the two of you, I think.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't understand what you're saying.  You mean he has to intend to provide evidence that he knows will be used at trial?  I don't think that's the test.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He's intending to accuse somebody.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
